data.text: Introduction

The Trust recognises that the attraction and retention of staff with certain skills is critical to the provision of an efficient, high quality service that achieves the best possible health outcomes for patients, at a sustainable cost. Homeworking on a regular or occasional basis is a recognised flexible working practice which, in appropriate circumstances, can help employees balance their work and personal lives, achieve business objectives and have a positive impact on the environment.
Homeworking is a term covering a variety of agreements which can include:-
Working almost entirely at home apart from carrying out regular or occasional duties/meetings onsite;
Splitting time between working at home a few days a week (depending on the agreement) with the rest of the time spent on-site;
Working from home only occasionally;
Travel related roles where the job entails significant journeys and the employees home is used as a base;

Having a temporary agreement to carry out certain duties/responsibilities from home, e.g. as a result of accident or injury that affects transport or to provide ‘protected' time to complete particular projects or reports.
There are many reasons why working from home may be an option for consideration, these include:-
Technology making it easier for some roles to be performed from any location;
Employees seeking flexibility in their working lives to achieve a more beneficial work/life balance, e.g. to take account of other responsibilities they may have for caring for family;
Rising costs and time of commuting.
This policy should be read in conjunction with the Trust's Flexible Working policy.
Scope

This policy applies to all employees of Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust (MEHT), Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust (SUHFT) and Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust (BTUH). It does not apply to Contractors, Bank staff, Agency or Volunteer workers.
It does not form part of the employee's contract of employment but is a statement of the Trust's current practice and may be changed from time to time.
Purpose

The purpose of this policy is to set out the Trust's framework for managing requests for homeworking or when considering options for how best a role can be carried out that will assist with the recruitment, retention and motivation of employees.

This policy should be used in all circumstances where there is a request or need for homeworking,  be  it  on  a  regular  or  frequent  basis.   Where  a  request  for homeworking is on a one-off basis, it is not expected that the full procedure should be adopted.
This policy aims to:-
Provide a clear and manageable procedure for homeworking
Provide the basis for a clear understanding of the homeworking scheme for the benefit of the Trust and the employee
Make clear the responsibilities of the manager and the homeworker
Ensure homeworkers work safely and securely with preventative measures for hazards or risks.
Definitions

table_items.text: Health and Safety and Risk Assessments (see appendix 5)
The Trust has a duty of care to its employees and should carry out a risk assessment before homeworking can be approved.
The Trust will not contribute to any costs that may be incurred as a result of working from home, e.g. heating and lighting.

It will be the responsibility of the employee to check if they will have to pay any business rates for working at home. The extent of use of the room or rooms, how often they are used and whether they are also used as living space will have a bearing. The Valuation Office Agency (part of HMRC) will be able to advise.
The employee will be expected to have a lockable secure storage area at home for Trust documents and equipment. Trust policies regarding data protection and information governance will apply.
The employee and line manager need to agree communication requirements between the employee, the manager and the

wider team. These should include:- - Time, method and frequency for general communication/updates - Time, method and frequency of supervision/appraisal sessions - Time and frequency of team meetings - Time and frequency of training/update sessions

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Managers

5.1.1 Managers are required to familiarise themselves with this policy and the related Flexible Working policy enabling them to fairly and appropriately manage requests made by members of their team for homeworking.

5.1.2 Managers  are  required  to  carefully  and  fully  consider  all  applications  for homeworking and to complete the required paperwork in a timely fashion. The Working from Home discussion checklist (appendix 3) should be used
5.1.3 Managers are required to complete with the employee the Checklist for Setting up Homeworking, see appendix

5.1.4 The  manager  is  responsible  for  meeting  with  the  employee  once  a  formal homeworking request is submitted. This meeting and written confirmation of the outcomes must be completed within  calendar days of receiving the request.

5.1.5 If the request is not agreed then the manager must write to the employee within 21 calendar days of the meeting setting out clear business reasons for the rejection of the request and notifying the employee of the appeals process. The letter should include the name and job title of the next in line manager who the employee may appeal the outcome with, should they wish to do so.

5.1.6 The  manager  is  responsible  for  monitoring  the  homeworking  arrangement  and reviewing it in accordance with this policy. The manager should ensure that the arrangement continues to be appropriate for both the employee and the service.
5.1.7 The manager must keep a record of homeworking applications and the outcome retained in the employee personal file.
5.1.8 The manager is required to agree with the employee working from home a plan ensuring regular communication and contact is maintained between the manager, the employee and the wider team.
Employees
5.2.1 Employees are expected to familiarise themselves with this policy as well as the Trust Flexible Working policy and procedure
5.2.2 Employees should complete the flexible working request application form (appendix
1) and submit it to their line manager for consideration
5.2.3 Employees should take into consideration the impact of their working from home request on the team and the service

5.2.4 Employees must give consideration to the fact that a homeworking arrangement may have contractual implications (e.g. pay, pension and other benefits) and they should discuss this with Human Resources or their Trade Union representative or Professional Body.
Human Resources
5.3.1  Human Resources are responsible for providing advice on homeworking arrangements and the relevant process to managers and staff.
Procedure and timelines for Making and Considering Requests for
Homeworking

For employees wishing to make a homeworking request, appendix 1: ‘Making a Flexible Working Request' form needs to be completed. This is required where the request to work from home is on a regular rather than a one-off basis.
The Flexible Working Arrangements – Timescales document (see appendix 4) should be followed.

The manager should arrange to meet with the employee to discuss the request within 14 calendar days of receipt of the request. The employee is allowed to be accompanied at the meeting by a Trade Union representative or current work colleague.

At the meeting, the manager should discuss the request in detail with the employee; exploring with them how they see it working for themselves, the team and the service as a whole. Confirmation as to how long the employee wishes the arrangement to be applicable for should also be confirmed.
In considering whether a request can be reasonably accommodated, the manager will have to assess the likely impact on:-
Patient care or quality of service delivery;
Any savings or budgetary constraints as a result;
Impact on the team:
Assess the likely management impact
All homeworking arrangements should be reviewed periodically and set timeframes for the reviews should be clearly set out.

Whether homeworking requests can reasonably be met, either in full or in part, will be a matter of judgement, balancing the impact on the individual of declining the request with the impact on the service and the rest of the team in agreeing to the request.

The Trust requires managers to evidence that they have considered every request seriously and made a business case assessment and that they are treating all members of the team fairly and consistently. The manager will only be able to refuse a request for homeworking if they can evidence that they have considered all the following:-
Any additional costs;
Ability to reorganise work amongst existing staff;
Ability to recruit additional staff;
Effect on ability to meet customer demands;
Sufficient work for the periods the employee proposes to work;
Planned structural change to the organisation.
The following should also be fully considered:-
Is the role suitable for homeworking;
Is the job holder eligible;
Is the home suitable;
Will homeworking be beneficial to the Trust and to the employee;
Have Health and Safety Risk Assessments been carried out;
What will be required in order to set up the employee to work from home;
Any taxation implications;
The employees attendance at the main office/base;
Security, including information governance arrangements at home and in transit.
All requests, including any appeals, must be considered and decided on within a period of 3 months from receipt, unless the manager agrees to extend this period with the employee.
In the event that a request for homeworking is refused or not met in full, the employee may apply again no less than 12 months from the date of their previous request.
Records of all applications and their outcomes should be retained on personal files in accordance with national statutory documentation retention periods.
Appeals

All employees have the right to appeal against any formal decision regarding their homeworking request. The procedure to be followed is contained within the Trusts Appeals Procedure and can be summarised as follows.

If the employee wishes to appeal, he/she must do so in writing to the next in line manager within 14 calendar days of receipt of written notification of the original decision. The letter must clearly state the grounds of appeal. However, they are encouraged to try and resolve the situation informally first, with support from HR if appropriate.
On receipt of the written appeal, the next in line manager will send a letter of acknowledgement to the employee within 10 calendar days of receipt.

In the event that an appeal is not submitted within the prescribed timescales it is received by the Trust ‘out of time', the Trust reserves the right to review the reasons for any delayed appeal and determine whether it will be considered.
The employees' rights to representation at the flexible working request meeting will apply equally to the appeal meeting.
The decision of the next in line manager is final. The decision will be notified to the employee within 10 calendar days.

As all flexible working and homeworking requests, including any appeal, must be considered and a decision made within a period of 3 months from first receipt, the manager must ensure that the appeal process is completed within the prescribed timescales, unless there is mutual agreement with the employee to extend this period.
Training Requirements

This policy is in immediate effect from its agreement date. There are no specific training requirements. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the Human Resources department.
Monitoring and Audit

All requests for homeworking and their outcomes under this policy and procedure will be monitored by the Human Resources department in partnership with the relevant Staff-Side Representatives. The aim will be to ensure that any requests for homeworking are managed appropriately as per this policy.

This  policy  has  been  reviewed  and  approved  by  the  Human  Resources departments and Staff-Side across Mid Essex/Southend/Basildon Group and will be implemented with immediate effect from its agreement date. This document will be available  electronically  on  the  Trusts'  Intranets.   Advice  and  support  on  the implementation of this policy is available via the Human Resources department.

This should be read in conjunction with the Trusts Flexible Working policy.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trusts aim to design and implement services, policies and procedures that meet the needs of our service, population and workforce, ensuring that none are placed at a disadvantage over others.
In order to meet these requirements, an equality impact assessment is used to assess all its policies, procedures and practices. This policy was found to be compliant with this assessment.

HOMEWORKING DISCUSSION CHECKLIST  APPENDIX 2

table_items.text: Service Need Is the work suitable for homeworking? Is it all the duties and responsibilities of the role, or specific tasks? If specific tasks, please indicate what these are. Is the employee skilled and able to work remotely? Would this have a positive or detrimental effect on service provision?

The employee making the request and their role Does the employee manage any other team members? If so, how will this be managed if working from home? How much technical or other support does the employee provide to the team? How will this be managed? How will office cover be maintained, for example, annual leave or sickness absence of colleagues?
Premises Where will the work take place? Is this a suitable location? Is there appropriate furniture in the premises? Are others at the premises affected by the arrangement?
Health & Safety Complete assessments for VDU and Workplace equipment

Security Check out the guidelines on the usage of mobile IT equipment. How will the property be looked after? How will confidential information be secured, particularly when using non-Trust computers? How will confidential material be disposed of? How will confidential material be transported between the site and the homeworkers premises?
What equipment is required? What will be provided by the Trust? What will the employee be providing? Is there an expectation of costs being reimbursed for these?
Base Does the employee retain a base within the Trust? Where can the employee store work items and use a desk and computer when in the workplace?
Communications When and where does supervision take place? How is the employee informed of team meetings and work information? How is isolation prevented?
Advice to employees Check out implications with home insurance, mortgage and tax
Terms and conditions Which existing terms and conditions do working from home affect? If a trial is successful, is it clear that changes would be made permanent?

table_items.text: Employee submits request using form in Appendix 1. Line Manager arranges meeting with the employee to discuss the request. The employee is allowed to be accompanied by a Trade Union representative or work colleague. Line Manager notifies employee in writing of their decision. This notification will either: Accept the request and establish a start date and any other action. No further meeting required; Or Confirm a compromise agreed at the meeting; Or Reject the request and set out clear business reasons for the rejection together with notification of the appeals process Appeal made and acknowledged Meeting held to hear employee's appeal against decision. The employee is allowed to be accompanied by a Trade Union representative or work colleague. Employee is notified in writing of the outcome of his/her appeal. The notification will either: Uphold the appeal, specify the agreed variation and start date; Or Dismiss the appeal, state the grounds for the decision and contain a sufficient explanation of the refusal End of process – No further right to appeal
The entire process, including any appeals must be completed within 3 months from when the line manager receives the request, unless the employee agrees to extend this period

data.text: The Trust and the employee can agree to extend any of these time limits. The Trust will record this agreement in writing, specifying the period to which the extension relates and the date on which the extension is to end. A copy of this record will be sent to the employee.
